title: 110_s1930
content: The Act titled "Combat Illegal Logging Act of 2007" aims to prevent illegal logging practices. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 define the term 'plant' as any wild member of the plant kingdom, excluding common food crops or cultivars not listed in certain international agreements or as endangered species. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 define 'take' as capturing, killing, collecting, and harvesting, cutting, logging, or removing plants. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 define 'take' as capturing, killing, collecting, harvesting, cutting, logging, or removing plants from protected areas without proper authorization or payment of required fees. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 define 'take' as capturing, killing, collecting, harvesting, cutting, logging, or removing plants from protected areas without proper authorization or payment of required fees. The amendments also prohibit the possession of plants taken, transported, possessed, or sold in violation of any foreign law or state law that protects plants or regulates the theft of plants from officially protected areas. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 prohibit the taking of plants from protected areas without authorization or payment of required fees. It also prohibits the possession, transportation, or export of plants in violation of foreign or state laws protecting plants. Effective 180 days from enactment, it will be unlawful to import any plant without filing a declaration containing the scientific name, value, quantity, and country of origin. Until the Secretary promulgates a regulation, a declaration for plant products must include the names of all possible plant species used or the country of origin if the species is unknown. The Secretary must review the implementation of requirements related to plant product declarations within 2 years of enactment. A report evaluating the effectiveness of the information required must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of the review completion. Recommendations for legislation to identify plants imported in violation of section 3 and an analysis of the impact of subsection (a) and (f) provisions are also included. The Secretary may promulgate regulations to limit requirements on specific plant products after conducting a review on the cost of legal plant imports and illegal logging practices. Public participation is required in the review process. The Secretary can modify requirements on specific plant products based on a review, and update section 7(a)(1) by replacing "section 4" with "section 3(f), section 4,".
